Entry.1:
3 16
Tel-El-Kebir

Last night I was on guard and today I am off duty untill 3 oclock:all this morning the artillery have been haveing a few shots,no doubt getting ready for our next campaign where ever that may be.I myself think it will be the gulf to have another go at Jonny the turk, and I am sure they will get something like they got on the Gallipoli peninsula. This place is getting rather warm and the flies are getting rather troublesome. Where we are now camped is where the English fought the Egyptians it is the old battle field of TelEl Kebir and the Battle took place more than 35 years ago, and even now one can go out and pick up bones of those who fell.I believe there was a good many killed here no doubt. This was an ideal ground for the Defenders of itbecause it is all

(4)

so open you can see for miles all around you This is where the English formed their famous Square which was Broken by the Egyptians in the Battle for Tel El Kebir

Camp
last week I went to Cairo to see if there was any money for me from Aust and I find that there is 5 pounds for me in the anglo Egyptian Bank.

Met Jack Margan yesterday also Bull Gurder.

(5)

Tel-El-Kebir
21st 3 16
today the prince of wales was here haveing a look round and when he was departing the troops lined the road and cheered for all they were worth.

Serapeum 29th 3 16
we left Tel El-Kebir on Sunday for Serapeumwhere we have now arrived after 3 weary days marching through the Sand. The first night we reached Massamah the second Moascar and the third day we crossed the Suez Canal and wealloted to our tents the distance being 45 miles. On the way down we were without water and whenever the men rushed any holes that they came to they were stopped by the General from drinking he saying that it was not fit for drinking.



(6)

18. 6.16
Somewhere in france

The Stretchers have arrived and they may be needed any time now. 4 men have to be on Duty byday and night on the Square in case any one gets knocked out
Entry.2:
6. 16
today we leave for a position nearer the fireing line. The name of this village is and is situatedabout 2½ miles behind the fireing line.The Germans are giveing the planesmore straff. The poor germans god forgive them because we will not.
Entry.4: We are now camped at Serapeumon the Side of the Canal where we arrived a few days ago from Tel El Kebir which is about 45 miles away and we had to walk at times without water in our Bottles.
Entry.6: has arrived once more and the boys are haveing great Catches I myself have been caught once.It is windy here today I have made several attempts to write a letter but the dust won't let me.
Entry.7: All day yesterday and again today it has been very dusty. Last night I shall not forget for some time to come there was 3 of us in the tent and were just going to bed when a duststorm struck us.
Entry.11:
afternoon from 4.30 Pte Norman and me for a stroll along the Beach 

McClintock
G T C
Entry.12:
16. 6.16
CaptMarks and Seargeant Clinen and W.O. rogers go to londonon 8 days leave. They were the first 3 to leave from the Batt.

12.4.16
today has been rather Dusty here and now it is about 7 am and there is a heavy Storm passing over and the tent is rocking like a ship in a heaveySea we are all Cursing the windfor Blowing So much we are covered with Dust from head to to foot, I have Eaten about 3 pounds of it. 

13.4.16
no improvment on last night weather plenty of Dust and more hell to go into.

(9)

These are the names of the men in our hut.
Sgt.Clark, S
Cp Thomas,K
CplBeech, S
PteMcClintock,S Phand
PteWild,U
PteSneesby, T
Pte Banning, Right m w

Pte Workman,right
Pte McKerlie,Killed
Pte Baxter,wounded
Pte Sipple, T
Pte Curley,wounded
 


(10)

5.6.16
time about 8.30 we will reach port some time tomorrow morning after 5 and a ½ daysail from Alexandria. Thank god thatwe have left Egypt S.S.S.S. We will land in france with a Smile because we knows that is where the germans are.

13.4.16
We clean out the tanks. They were very Dusty.
Entry.13:
RMS transylvaniaat sea
We left Alexandria on friday morning last bound for france which we will reach late tomorrow night or Early next morning up till now nothing of any notice has occured no Submarines Sighted yet there is 2 parades per day on the ship one at 9.30 and the other at 4.30. We are now passing the islands of Sardinia. We passed Cape last night also islands of Create
Entry.14:
France 20.6.16
Nothing much Doing last night only a few of the guns Speaking. Meek has got Boils on his neck pity they were not on his toungue and then he would not be able to talk So much.
Entry.15:
5.16
on Board Ship at Sea
The food on Board this Ship is rotten and not worthing Eating it is a damn disgrace the way the men are looked after the officers do pretty well. Theywill watch that part of the Business it will hurt some of them when the war is finished. They will have to go home and live on Bread and fat.
Entry.16:
6 16
time 8.30 pm
Seven of our aeroplanes have just returned from the German lineswhere they have been observing. During our occupation of the

Gallipoli peninsula I have seen hundreds of Shells thrown at the planes but here it is thousands and what I have just seen has Surprised me. The Enemy have just covered the sky with Schrapnel it is a grand Sight to See the way our take it. There is nothing to frighten them away if a Shell happens to hit any where near them theyjust turnand say fire again.

Serapeum 14.5.16
Whenever will we get away from this place we have been in this Camp for the past 6 weeks and we are all getting tired of the place. The life is dead to us. wWen we first came to this place things were one mass of Curios But now this place is nothing But Dust and Sand. The tempture here today is 120 in the Shade.
Entry.17:
28.5.16
today we have to take our clothes to the other side of the Suez Canal to get them fumigated This is to kill any vermin that may be in the uniforms. Theydo want us to in france. Will we be Sorry when we disembarkat Marseilles I dont think so.

May 31st 16
tonight we commence to leave dusty Egypt for france. We will reach Alexandria about 2 am, The journey being 10 hours. Not one of us are sorry we are going.

(14)

22.6.16
Before we were out of Bed this morning the germans opened fire on one of our Battries it is only about 300 yards away they must have put 100 Shells into the positions the Shells being about 8 inch. The rumour goes that they put one gun out of action I dont know if it were true. The german aeroplanes came over our lines this morning. They were the 1st hun planesthat I have seen over here our anti aircraft guns opened fire on them one or 2 went to close to them,they turned and went for their lives,no casualties in the 13 yet. There is some talk of us going into the first line trenches on Saturday.
Entry.18:
Bang Bang Crack
That is the Sound of the Bursting Shells today They are on our right, left and in the front and also behind. The ones behind are our own and will not harm us the ones in front will. The boys are watching the huns Straffing our planes gott Straff the Kaiser and his Staff.

Somewhere in france
Entry.19:
We are now about 3 miles behind the fireing line and within range of the german guns, and all day there has been Shells Bursting about 300 yards away They have not managed to get them into our billetsbut may land one here any time. from where I am writing I can see the German observation Balloons. They like us use Balloons for the purpose. There is some talk of the 13 going into the trenches soon
The night before last

(16)

the Enemy made a gas attack on our troops. The rumour goes that there was 400 Canadians cooped it. The has just burstedabout 300 yards away 6 inch Shells only a couple of them about an hour ago. I was watching a shell bursting in the air and I have not seen any smoke like it before. The germans have just Set fire to a house by shell firewhich I believe was Burnt to the ground. This means that some poor unfortunate persons will be without a home tonight and they call this war. We troops all expect to meet our fate on the field But these people who are not fighting have too put up with a lot that is not known to many. Some of them will not leave their villages under any circumstances.Before thewar no doubt this is where many of them
Entry.20: reared their families and now find it hard to leave and some of those who were Brought up haveingtheir lives for france and many more will do the same before the war is ended. Not one of us likes war no it is hell and was not meant for the men to die the way they are doing in this war. The germans are using all sorts of cowardly methods to kill their enemies,firstly the gas which has not proved so successful as theygermans hoped it would be and then there is the tear shell. Only yesterday morning we went through the gas but not the german gas it was demonstration to show us how inaffective their gas is against our gas helmets. We did not feel any after affects. This
Entry.21:
Tear Shell when it Burns in the vicinity of you if you are close enough it she will make you Blind. The Kaiser or whoever is to blame for this war will get the punishment which they so deserve when the war is finished. There is no doubt about it we are going to win this war.One has only to walk behind the lines to see that.

18.6.16
today we have been issured with fags one pkt.and one Box matches. I believe we get paid tonight the first since the 25.5.16 we want it badlywant it. There is no money in the . The germans are giveing our aeroplanes a little bit of Straff.
Entry.22:
19.6.16
There is nothing much doing today. I went to See miss concert party it was not up to much it was held about 1½ miles along the road. I got a hair cut, the first for about 3 months. It is very windy at present the enemy may take advantage of it and use the gas.Wrote 2 letters one to Annie and one to Essie. English mail comes but no Aust . I hope we get some soon. Enemy used gas last night we were called out and had to put our helmets on in case of a emergency. we stood to for a hour and a half waiting for it too reach us but it failed to do so. The New Zealanders attacked the germans last night we have not heard the result yet,I hope it was a success.
Entry.23:
18.6. 16 British Bombardment of the German Trenches

last night about the hour of 12 pm the british artillery opened up on the german trenches,it was a beautiful Sight,but alas a terrableone. The English sent up Star Shells in thousands and when they bursted in the there was nothing but colors of all kinds,blue green red and many others and then the fun began. The guns opened all along the line,the noise was terrific.The cause for this Bombardment was I believe the enemy used the gas on our boys and the gun fire was to raise it from the ground by doing this we compel the gas to rise and it is not so harmful to us. The gas is heavier than air.
Entry.24:
France
21st 6.16
There was not much Doing only a little Bombardment last night some of our boys went into the trenches for 72 hours Sergt C. H. has been there since yesterday afternoon the name of the village we are in is called
Entry.25:
time 4.30 pm
at the present moment there is a intence Bombardment going on. the Germans are giveing it to our Boys hot and strong and we are Straffing them. while I am writing this I can hear nothing but the Shells coming and going Bang in the air. the Germans are now trying to get one of our aeroplanes. there is a Battry close by and the Germans have been after it Since 7 pm this morning but they have not managed to knock them out

There is agreat Crowd of the men watching the shells falling

(22)

a Shell may lob amongst them any moment. They will catch it ifone does. The huns are still after the planes I have not seen any Shot Downas yet. They are rather Difficult to hit when they are going through the air 
time 5 pm
The Enemy are Still Bombarding our positions and we are doing the same to them I have seen a peculiar Shell Bursting in the air taffy reckons it is gas But I don't think so. the Enemy set the town Hall on fire this morning at ......
Entry.26:
6.16
nothing doing on the front today on account of a thunderstorm that is passing over

24 nothing

25th 6.16
This afternoon our aeroplanes attacked theirenemy look out postand a observation Balloon and also downed a Taube. The Enemy Shellthe village of Erquingham

(23)

26.6.16
France. time 4pm

up till the present nothing of any note has occured the weather looks like being very warm. one of our aeroplanes has just returned from the German trenches. the rumour goes that we go into the trenches tomorrow night some time. I dont know if we will because one cannot believe what he hears here. I have spent all my pay so there will have too be a limited Supply of Smokes untill I can manage to get some more money. one of the men who has been out in the trenches Since Saturday last tells us that our first man Killed since we came to France is Pte Wild of B Company Since we have been in this Campaign we have lost about 10 men The onethat got Killed last night was assisting the 18th Btn in a raid on the German trench Sergeant has been sent to the 5th F.A
Entry.27:
29 6 16 France

we came into the Trenches last night about 2pm we arrived we are now settled down in the Dressing Station Sincewe came here we have had a few men wounded. Cpl Barnes is lying Dead out side the door he got hit on the head. he went through Gallipoli with the Battalion and fought in the landing on
Entry.28:
Things have not been too bad since we came not much artillery going on that is all that can harm us here as we are supposed to occupy a gas and shell proof Dugout but I think if a was to land on top it would be about up with us

(25)

29th 6 16
France

During this last couple of weeks our Boys have been Keeping the Germans thinking we have raided their trenches a couple of times lately and last nighttheystarting throwing Bombs into their ownBarb wire This amused our Boys The other night some of the 18th Btn took some prisoners and they pinched all their Buttons as souvenirs. one of them was and before he could reach our lines our Boys were after him while they were doing this a Shell from the Germans wounded the whole lot of them
Entry.29:
The Trenches
30.6.16

Last night our Boys carried out a raid on the germans. itseems to have been a success because there was only one man hit with our own trench mortar not seriously. how these raids are carried on first of all the men Blacken their faces and do not carry rifles. The carry a Stick with a Spiked head on it. The artillery Bomb the Enemies trenches and then all of a sudden stop and then our men go forward and when they are finished the artillery cover their retreat thus keeping the Germanin his Sec or Third line Trench
Entry.30: This afternoon a fleet of 20 of our aeroplanes went over the german lines no doubt for the purpose of dropping Bombs on their positions. They all returned safely it was a greatsight to see them going through the air they looked like a flock of Eagles. The Enemy fired on them with schrapnel But did not get within miles of them. Just before the planes went across the Enemy started to put some shells into D Coys Billets. one shot hit a house and you could See Bricks going in all Directions. I dont know if they managed to get any Body But I am afraidthey must have as they were right in amongst them. There has been no wounded men come
Entry.31: into the Dressing Stn today and only one last night a private from the 17th Battalion Pte Stokes was in this Dug out yesterday afternoon with six of his mates when the Germans put a bomb amongst them. Pte Stokes had his face Blown right away. The poor chap was only a boy his age being Eighteen. to young for this Sort of work. the other Six with him had better luck one Being wounded and four Suffering from Shell Shock remainin the fireing line the name of this place is Bois Grenier. Curley, Wild, Sneesby Foster Knox pay us a today
Entry.32: The food here is not too considering we are on active service. These are amongst the issue that we get Butter pickles Bread. These things we did not see much of while we were on the Gallipoli penn.the tucker here is much Better. mail came today But no letters for me I wrote about 8 this afternoon. we received word this morning that the English troops at la Basse took 300 yards of trenches off the german the french are Doing well at Verdun. The number of troops engaged at la Basse was thirty two Divisions I think within this next 6 weeks the allies will make a big offencive on this front.
Entry.34:
We had rather a busy night no sleep on account of the wounded coming the Germans managed to get a couple of Bombs amongst our Boys

I have just come back from the 4th field amb where I and Banneyhad been with a case Shell Shock.
our artillery gave the Germans a little Straff they will not return the fire on account of our aeroplanes who are watching for the German gun positions.
A couple have been killedup till the present and a few wounded

(31)
Entry.35:
This morning I have had a look at the first line trenches and my first Empressions are that they look fine. The Dugouts being much Better than they were on Gallipoli line There we had the Hills to protect us and they were much better than the DOs If a shell manages to get at them it will be all up. from the first line we went over to an old farm house to some water for Drinking purposeswe also had a look at the enemy position from the distance they are in the wood. There was a few men killed last night is in the Dressing Station having a yarn to us he tells us that

(32)

that the Germans put some aerial torpedos over into their trench these wepons are giveing it to our Boys lately This sort of thing is what gives them Shell Shock. Things are quite so faryou cant hear a Shot being fired But at the hour of 12 pm that is when they start to Straff and then there are some flying about

I have just seen the mostly gastly sight in my life. The pioneers just Brought a man in from the trenches and the poor chap had half his face blown right away his friend was Blown into peices and some parts of him was found 70 yards away. my god the

(33)

Sights we see are awful. people who only sit and read about the war have no idea what the troops have to through Since I left australia I have seen many terriable Sights and I Dont think that I Seen anything in the landing at gallipoli to come up to what I have seen here During this last couple of Days awful is not the word for it it is hell upon earth right Enough and yet do the Boys want peace. yes we all want peace But we realise that it must be with complete Victory for the arms of the allies

A German taubehas just come across our lines and has penetrated our lines for a good Distance in

(34)

This is the first German aeroplane that I have seen over our lines our anti aircraft guns are after him But are shooting a good deal short of the mark he is up a great Distance he looks like a Sky lark in the clouds our planes will be after him shortly as we are masters of the air 100 shots have now gone after the taube. There is going to be a big Boombardment of the german trenches tonight By our Boys we are going to Straff Fritz for all we are worth

(35)
Entry.36:
last night the 14th Battalion made a raid on the german Trenches. from what I can hear it was not a success. Eighty men went out and only Twenty Seven returned fifteen of them being wounded. They got hung up in the German Barb wire The artillery was violent
News has Just come through that there is thirty missing in last nights raid and twenty Casualties. 2 men came in this morning.

The Germans put up a sign this morning Saying Dont inflict to many casualties peace in two months time. We will wait and see I think they

(36)

are Trying have a joke with us. buy all counts they Dont like the Bombardment our Boys have been giveing them this last week

one of our aeroplanes was over the german lines this afternoon it received the usual Straffing. "D" Company releives C Company tonight nothing much Doing in the artillery line this Evening. that will come tonightabout 12 pm the usual time

Brigadier General monash came along the Trenches today and had a look at the Boys. no casualties During the day The german machine gun has started

(37)
Entry.37:
france

The germans attack the 14th Battalion last night They gave our Boys an un merciful hours Bombardment it was kept up for about 12 hours we have not heard how many casualties they had we only had one man Killed During the past 24 hours and none wounded

it has been raining here all day. The ground is very Sloopyour Boys Bombard the Germans this evening. The Huns have not replied to our fire. I have been reading the account of the great offencive on this front we seem to be getting right into fritz anyhow it is time that we Done something We

(38)

have been idle long enough we all hope that the adancewill continue not because we are not in the we are allways ready when the order comes and I Dont think that will be very long.
I went to C Company this afternoon for the Doc to warn 5 men to return to the Dressing Station Could only find one Jim the other 4 are missing there is a rumour that A Comp is going to have a go tonight hope they Do not get knocked about too much

Lieut boccardfound a message from the Germans this morning asking how Do you like our trench mortars we hate yours

(39)

your artlillery is Rotten what is ours like no Doubt some of the huns have a little humour. They wont have to much when our boys Start to move forward oh Dear no not they

our guns that have just been put into position opened up on Fritzs trenches this Evening maccarthy went to Erquinghamthis afternoon hope he brings back something nice to Eat the food issure in the trenches is the best tha I have seen since I left Australia in 1914

(40)
Entry.38:
very Dull here today I went to the waterfarm this morning with Sgt Clark and McCarthy also Workman we fixed things up. we are going to get a warm time up there shortly our boys are putting two trench mortars along side the tank when they start the germans will try and find them with heavey artillery and the tanks will go Sky high we threw some Big Shells at the germans today

They gave us a few Big uns too

The germans Bombarded our trenches this Evening 2 men supposed to have been killed in D Company There was 2 wounded in X Coy

(41)

one was private mason he has just left the Dressing Station for the fourth field ambulance he had rather a bad knock. one wound in the stomach 3 in the Knee and one in each foot makeing Six in all there was not a mermor from from him he Stuck to it like anAustralian Does when he gets wounded. issured with tobbaco this afternoon. Bonney is not feeling too well to day. I hope he is better tomorrow. I have Sent to Erquingham for 6 tins of good flake cigarettes. wont I have a time after meals when I can sit down on Couch (the floor) and smoke till the cows come home. I took Sgt major Compton to the 4th F.A. he goes to fort 

(42)
Entry.39:
7 1916

The artillery was on the left was going some last night it being the most violent that I have heard on this front. There was also a gas alarm at midnight we were told to have our helmets ready After siting up in bed for about an hour we received the order no gas the horns were blowing for they were worth this being the alarm for the gas. It was us 
being
 giveing the huns a taste of there own medicine The Enemy threw about 15 Big Shells about 100 yds away. They were trying to find the Battery

(43)

This afternoon the Germans were trying to find our head quarters with heavey artillery they lobed them all round the Dressing Station and Drove me out. I went into the front trenches as that was the safest place they did not do any damage how they tried to find the HQ was the first shot went about 200yards wide of the mark the next 150and each shot they reduced 50 yards This is what we call feeling for their object. They Knocked the machine guns dug outs into the air no one was hit

There was a taube up observeing for the Germans artillery I think we get relieved tomorrow night by the 15 Battalion and a good one it is too



(44)

violent artillery Duels on our right and left have just received word that the total number of prisoners takeing in the great Franco- British offencive reaches thirteen thousand Good Boys Keep on going you will soon be in Berlin and have the two Willies By the Heels.
Entry.40:
very wet here today went to water farm this morning and filled to tanks thing are rather quite so far here today not many shells flying round But I suppose there will bethe usual Straff tonight only one man wounded in the past 24 hours

(45)
Entry.41: There has not been much Doing here today only a fewoccasional shots going Down to C Company Billets no one has been hit
Entry.42:
last night our Guns opened a Bombardment of the German trenches commencing at 10-30 and ending at 11 pm. Then our trench mortars gave them something for half an hour. we expected the germans to retaliate vigriously But they did not their reply was very feeble only one man being slightly wounded. A German plane come over our lines this morning but after our anti aircraft guns put a few shots close to him he turned tail



(46)

and went for his Dear life. received more good news from the russian front yesterday also the Franco British front who have now captured 15000 prisoners

We leave here for Steen JEEtomorrow night and after a few days rest then on to La Basse or Ypres to assist in the great offencive. are we Downhearted. no. I went to water this morning. word has just come through that the russians have taken 12000 prisoners 300 officers and 45 guns and crossed the river The Germans gave us a little Straff this afternoon they put 80 Big Shells over and they were Dropping all round the Dressing Stn some only going about 20 yards away

(47)

We all Done a Skoot out ofthe Station We can all schrapnel but not high explosives if one was to lob on the top of it there would be about 9 or 10 men Buried there is no escape at all. no one wounded So far to day our artillery on the right are Straffing the Germans this afternoon
received good news from the allies fronts to day

two German Taubes over our lines at 6 pm two of ours gave chase. The Germans put Schrapnel all over the Sky after them But as usual missed rumoured that the Socialist party are causing some trouble in Germany. They can End the war quicker than we can

(48)
Entry.43:
7th 1916

2 german Taubes over our lines this morning our artillery open fire on the enemy trenches at 4.00 this morning This is rather an unusual to Start. we nearly allways commence about midnight one of our planes fly over the german at 1 pm The germans give it a little Straff General Cox walks through the trenches this morning and Bid the men good day. half the Battalion get releived tonight and go to Steen JEE. Filled 2 water cans for two men wounded to day so far none killed.

(49)
Entry.44:
7. 1916

last night was the quietest that we have had Since we came into the fireing line. The
Entry.45:
Battalion releived the 13th last night we leave here tonight for Steen JEE 3 men wounded in the last 24 hours Taffy cut his finger badly last night and had to get the Doc to put four stitches in it

time 9 pm
we are all ready to go when the 29th Btn amc come they ought to be here now The Germans are putting high explosives Shells into Bois Grenier. one 39th Battalian man wounded to day the first of that Btn. his name was Cochran he was not Badly hit Slight wounds on the head and the worst one was on thehip we go to Erquinghanto night also



(50)

we rest untill 1 pm tomorrow when we resume our march on to Steen JEEwhich we ought to reach about 6 pm tomorrow my today from received a 

12th July 1916

we left the trenches at 2.30 this morning and arrived at Erquinghem at 4.40 here we rest untill 1 pm and then resume our march again we go to SteenJEE.
foot Sore and weary we arrive at Steen JEEtime 6.30. we leave here tomorrow



(51)
Entry.46:
We are leaving here in a few minutes for the rail station we do not know where we are going But most of the Boys think we are going on the Somme to assist in the push there.

had a good nights sleep last night the best since we left the village for the fireing line 3 weeks ago.

left Steen JEE10 pm arrived at Bailleul 12 pm entrained at 12.15 pm and departed at 12.30. arrived at Candas6.30. left 7 am on 7 miles march finishing at 11 pm foot Sore and weary oh who wouldent be a Soldiers

(52)

14 . 7 . 1916

we are now in Billets at a little village. We are standing by ready to move off at ½ hours notice. we have 20 miles to do tonight oh what a pleasure to look forward too This village is not Bad plenty of wine and not much food

(53)
Entry.47:
we are now in a little Village where we arrived last night we are now standing by ready to move off at half hours notice we have no idea where we are going to but we do know that we have Something like a 20 miles march in front of us. rumours go that we will be marching for the next three days only a few men fell out on the march from Candasto here But I think there will be a great number fall out tomorrow on account the bad Boots and hard roads. I went up to the Village this morning and did not see any thing worth to mention. only all the houses are Estaminets.

15 7 1916

time 1 pm. we are about 4 miles from home on a rout march and are now haveing Dinner in a wheat field the cause for this march is the men have made Damn fools of themselves Drinking and the general sent the whole Division out to keep them away from the pubs. we are now Billeted at DomartI think we will push on tomorrow and get nearer the fireing line we are now about30 miles from where the big push is going on 

(55)

general over us monash goes as head of the 3rdaustralian Division he will be missed in the Brigade

I joined 17th Btn 2/12/17

(55)
Entry.48: There is nothing much to mention today we went on a rout march of about 10 miles the reason for this being comeing from Candasto Dormartthe general says there was no Dicipline on the march and gave us this to Cure us
Entry.49:
we are on our way to the front we left Domartat 4.30 this evening on a 9 miles march to naourswhich we reached at about 6.30 pm.

(56)
Entry.50: we are now settled Down in Billets at naourswe expect to leave here in a few days time we are going to march right up to the front which is about 20 miles we will get there in about 8 Days time
Entry.51:
1916

raining here today very uncomfortable we get paid some time today the church Bells are ringing and have been all night. we are here for about 9 Days

time 6 pm

(57)

I am now out for a walk with Bonney and Baxter and must get Down onthe roadside to Describe what the Scene is like we are surrounded by beautyful and fieldsof all sorts of Beautyful flowers poppys and what not. the frenchman who would refuse to fight for france wants executing god one would be proud to Die on such ground as this that I now look upon. my pen cannot write what I think of it

(58)
Entry.52:
it is a bright Sunny day and we are getting the full Benefit from it Fraser is Sick and going to the field ambulance. not much Doing otherwise. we were paid yesterday receiving more good news from the russian front. The anglo British offencive in the west is going on first rate taken after ten days hand to hand fighting

The war is now costing Britain 6 millions Daily

(59)
Entry.53:
7 . 1916

I went to Domart this morning on one of the Sigs Bikes I had to take the a.a.m.s report in and the Journey was first rate going but coming home was hilly and the old Cychad to be pushed all the way I left naoursat 10.30 and arrived back at 1.20 the Distance was 19 miles return next time I go there I want a motor car and some one to Drive it oh yes

nothing much Doing otherwise the troops have gone out on a rout march the english attacks are going on well.
we will be amongst it very soon

(60)
Entry.54:
nothing much Doing today we are supposed to be leaving here about Sunday &went up to the amb with pte who is Suffering from toncolitisand there went to CaptHenderson and got the teethforceps off him for Beechly to Drain Sgt Coles tooth and took the a.a.m.s report Yesterday afternoon with pte Baxter I went to the caves that are Situated about half a mile out of the village and had a good look underneath them They were Something after the style of the pyramids underneath Chapels of all sorts and in memory of many Saints france is a very Religious Country and no matter

(61)

where one rambles too he will allways See altars on the roadside we changed our Billets this morning and now we are in the house where a french Doctor lives this morning while Sick parade was on he was rather interested and was sayingwhat he thought of the Cases.

Williams of the 13th Battalion Died a few Days ago from pneumonia



(62)
Entry.55:
today we go for a rout march to Flesselles the distance from NaoursBeing about 9 miles return Journey This was not enough walking for Baxter and I we had to come away without tea and walkto Havernasabout another 7 miles return what do you think of us Deserveno rest at all

received a letter from Both Essand Tess I am now in a shop at Havernas going to buy Something to quench our thirst

July 22nd
somewhere in france
1916

(63)
Entry.56: nothing doing today went for a stroll with Charlie. received a letter from Ess and Tess
Entry.57:
time 1.30 I am on Duty at the water tank nothing Doing otherwise we are leaveing here tomorrow have no idea where we are going too But theSome is

(64)
Entry.58:
We left Naours at 8.45 this morning and marched about 6 miles nearer the fireing line we rest here for 24 hours and then go onto the last billets which are about another Six miles ahead we are going to the Somme to assist in the big offencive thatis nowtaking place the first australian Divisions are in action and rumours go that they were Cut up badly but not before they gained their object. the germans were Supposed to have flooded them out of their trenches. we have a great amount of Calvery waiting untill the next line is taken and then they are going to act in a way that the germans wont like. I went to Talmasyesterday with Charlie Baxter

(65)
Entry.59:
nothing much has occured today we arrived in this village yesterday we marched from naours to rubempre. we leave here some time tomorrow for our last Billets which will not be far from the fireing line

27th July 1916
Warloy

This morning we were called at 5 oclock and told to get ready to move at once but Did not leave until 9 oclock after marching about

(66)

eight miles we arrived at our Destination This is our last billets, from here we go into the fireing line There is a rumour that we are going up tomorrow as reserves But I Dont think it can be true as there is many things that we are short of and must get before we go to meet the troops The first aust Division are coming out of the line the 12th Batt passedthrough this village this morning looking very much Knocked up they have had a rough time of it in the big push on the Somme wehave to receive our up their and we are sure to catchit hot and Strong

(67)

28th
Entry.60:
france
Warloy

There is not much Doing today the weather is nice and hot last night the first Australian Division came out of the trenches they were on the Somme taking part in the great push They still Kept the good name of the australians up and did not our name that we made on gallipoli The first Battalion must have got it rather hot because there were only about 300 hundred of them came back with their Battalion the Second Seems to have suffered just as bad if not worse Their only about 250 from thisBattalion left. one poor chap that I asked about was Killed in the Charge his name was G Corrigon. The third and fourth Battalions are not soweak as the 2 former Battalions

(68)

they were a gaylot of boys as they swung past Singing all Sorts of Songs not forgetting Aust. we'll be there.
They were there right enough and will be there again before the offencive is finished There was a great number of German helmets with the Boys which they prized more than anything elsethat was in their possion and rifles and pistols were another trophy which was very promminent amongst them. one Chap perched up on top of a timber waggon had a goat with him I Dont Know if he captured it but everything points that he did the way he had his arms round it you would think he was curting his best girl. we are now in a village its name is - and is situated about 7 miles behind the fireing line. we are stopping here for

(69)

for a while and then go up and releive the 2nd Division who are now in the trenches The first Division were in for about 4 Days and I Suppose the
Entry.61:
will Do the Same length of time and then us. are we Downhearted no but we soon will be. There is a concert in the village Square tonight. post 14 letters today the last until we come out from the big push. There is a rumour that austria is Sueing for peace hope she is and getsit it will go a long way to finish this warbut She must take what we give her or be crushed completely which will be the result if she continues with the war turkey and bulgaria will Share a Similar fate and germany will not be much more

(70)

allies peace terms

the allies have Submitted their peace terms to germany and this is what they are Supposed to be. of Course this is only a rumour I have not read it officially The german navy goes to england also heligoland and germany must pay a big endemnity to england. to France goes alsas lorriane and other territory. Italy gets a big Slice of austria and Servia a lump of Bulgaria while turkey ceases to exist in Europethe Dardanelles remaining a free port with russia the main nation in the Sectorengland also has all the german marine Shipping These terms are very Staggering to Germany and ones that I Dont think She will accept at least not for the present. She will continue to fight to the last man but we will be at her in the line and she will have totake any

(71)

anything that we offer of course there may be no truth in england offering her these terms. I myself Dont think She has I have only put them Down in the Diary as I just heard of it
Entry.62:
I was paid 40 franks yesterday nothing Doing today we are Standing by ready to march out at 1½ hours notice we are going up to the big push and will very likely be there before tomorrow night or it may be tonight about 50 reported Sick this morning one man was sent in field ambulence with ear trouble.

Warloy

(74)
Entry.63:
7th 1916
Warloy
France
time 5 pm

we have just received 3 hours notice to get ready and move out at 6.30 pm we are now waiting for the order to move. time 6.30. we have now received word that we are not going tonight. oh this is lovely we handed our blankets in last night and we had to Sleep on the hard brick floor with only an overcoat on and the medical cars will have to be unpacked again in the morning this will be the third time that we have packed it. in the village we handed our felt hats in and now we are going about in the Steel helmets and they are a good weight on our heads. The name of this village is Warloy - Baillonabout 10 miles from Albert

(75)
Entry.64:
nothing Doing today took a patient to the 4th F.A. and seen two men that was gassed by the Germans one Died while I was there and the other one coming round very close by but I am he will Die or be a cripple for Life poor chap

George





(76)
Entry.65:
France
Warloy

about Dinner time today four german aeroplanes Come over the village but Did not Drop any bombs our anti aircraft guns opened fire without any affect. fragments of Shells were falling in the village and one unexploded 12 pounder Dropped behind the
Entry.66:
Bn Q.M.Store

(78)

We went out this morning and had a sham fight and we go out again tonight at 9.30 and return at 12 pm While we were out this morning we rested in the aerodrome and while we were there we seen many planes go up and many alight.

(79)

if the German airman that were over and knew that they were so close to an aerodrome I think they would have Dropped bombs. no one was hit in this mornings raid The 12 Brigade left for Albert tonight we leave Soon now the 12th is a part of our Division

H and C Coy went to Delville Wood on Sunday

(80)

6 men and one officer have been wounded out of these 2 Coys There are out Digging Graves and a fatigue party

I had my boots mended today So did Spud

(81)

August 2nd
nothing Doing today
Entry.67:
nothing much Doing today the weather is fine
Warloy
Entry.68:
we are leaving for the fireing line tonight which is about 8 miles from here the rumour goes that our Division is going to make a big charge tomorrow night to commerate the Declaration of war between england and germany We all hope that it will turn out asuccess The name of this village is Warloy Baillionand we have not had a bad time During the 9 days that we have been Billeted in it

(82)
Entry.69:
Albert

we are now a couple of hundred yards out of Albertand within reach of the enemy guns all last night there was a rollingBombardment and it was the worst that ever I have heard including the landing on gallipoli Star Shells were continually going up and remind one of empire day. up above our aeroplanes are Skipping through the air. now and again one will fly over head quarters and drop a message. there is 20 of our observation Balloons in the air and one of the germans

(83)

the enemy shelled albert this morning when one comes into these french villages he wonders are the german a civilized race. albert is all in ruins caused by the German Shells I suppose before the war there was a population of 7 or 8 thousands and to house them all would take a great many houses. there is hardly one undamaged. the germans seem to try and Break all the Churchs. up here from where I am writing this I can look upon that was once a beautiful church. at the present it has Shell holes all through it and a beautiful Statue of our lady is hanging from the Stepple

(84)

with its hands pointing to the ground this may indicate the down fall of Germany. one man was wounded this morning belonging to the 13 transport. we leave here tomorrow for the first line trenches
Entry.70:
anniversary of Suvlabay landing one year ago - -
to day we were putting our equipment in rest gulleys on gallipoli waiting for the order to move out and charge and capture which we failed to do. it was won and lost again and the turks held it until the last



(85)

at this very hour we were listening to our warships and land Batteries Bombarding the turkish positions and nowat the present moment I am watching our guns Bombarding the germans positions. the artillery is violent. if one were to have asked me this time last year were I would be in 1916 I would have answered Still on gallipoli. our boys took 2 lines of trenches last night the germans were Shelling albert all last night we are now in TaraValley and may move up to the line tomorrow

(86)
Entry.71:
Sausage gulley Somme

arrived in the above named gulley this morning from taravalley the guns in this gulley are many
Entry.72:
Somme

nothing much Doing so far today the artillery are keeping a Steady fire on the german trenches our Boys are going to attack the germans tonight
Entry.73:
Somme

last nights attack very successful. our Brigade advanced 500 yards and captured the german trench without any opposition and took Some

(87)

prisoners who came through this morning the Bombardment was timed to Start at 9.20 and at that very sec hundreds of our guns Started. there was nothing But one mass of flames coming from the mouths of the guns and Death at the enemy. The roar of the Shells going through the air was Deafening the Sky was lit up with Bursting Schrapnel and Star Shells were up and Down in thousandsturning Darkness into Daylight

(88)
Entry.74:
Somme
france
1916

time 2 pm

we are now lined up ready to go on the front line trenches the
Entry.75:
Brigade are having another stunt tonight. time 4.15 pm. after couple of hours marching we arrived at the D Stn But oh what a time we have had in reaching here. just about 20 yards out a Shell Burst within 7yards of the post and Ithought for the moment that we were all goners

(89)

But I was the only one that was Doing anydamage
we hope the Boyscome off well tonight
Entry.76:
Somme front

we are now of the fireing line we have been in the line for the past 6 days. we leave Albert for Warloyon the above Date
Entry.77:
we are now Billetted in the same place that we were in before we went intothe line mcafferyand were Both Killed in action

(90)
Entry.78:
Warloy

we are leaving here this morning for pernoiswhich is 12 miles away. time 5 pm. we have not gone to pernoisBut are camped out under the trees in a village near Talmaswe are footsore and tired
Entry.79:
pernois

we are resuming our journey this morning and will reach pernoissome time this afternoon the Distance is 6 miles. time 2.30 pm. we have just arrived at the above village and they seem to be rather quiet here
Entry.80:
pernois

Still in pernois there is of us remaining here for 10 days rest

 

(91)

But I Dont think that Can be right as the first and second aust Division passed us going Back to the line. There is some talk of Capt phillips leaving the Battalion. not one of the a.m.care Sorry. hehis a rotter of the 1st water
Entry.81:
pernois

Capt phillips leaves us in a few Days time for good thank heavens we are getting rid of him

21st pernois

nothing Doing to Day

22nd pernois

time 1 pm we have just received

(92)

orders to get ready and move by one thirty we are going Back to the same front line. remain at Talmastonight and go on tomorrow morning

23rd Talmas

we arrived in the above named village at 5.30 yesterday afternoon we are going on this morning we camp in a wood tonight just outSide warloy. we are Dure in the line on the 28th of this month. lets hope we come out alive. this will make 6 times that I have been into the trenches and I have a Bullet mark for each time and one over

G McClintock

(93)

24th August 1916
Vadencourt Wood

we arrived here last night and are camped in the woods just outside the village. from this position one has a great view of the surrounding country which is very Beautiful. I counted 35 of our observation Balloons in the air this afternoon nothing much Doing otherwise

The new M.O. gives a first aid Lecture this morning which wasvery interesting

G McClintock

(94)

Pte J Kingdon Esq

perth
western australia



(95)

25th Aug 1916
Vadencourt wood

there was another fall in Stars last night. god what is the AIF coming too. here we have men who have not seen more than days fighting giveing commands over men that left aust in 1914 if the old colonel was here he would cry when he seen how the battalion is officered. Why these men get preference Beats me and is certainly an insult against those men that fought in the landing at anzac no encouragement is given to the oldmen

(96)

and those that have 2 years Service those that received Stars last night were

J Allen old Battalion
Brown old Battalion
Morgan
Smith 11th rein
Patrick
Cole
 old Battalion
 2nd rein

oh how thankful I will be when I get out of this army englandcan go to hell I will neverlift a finger again for her only for aust do wefight for now

we have received word that we leave here at 10 oclock tomorrow

(97)

for albert

25 Aug 1916
Albert

after three hours marching we arrived at albert. we are all camped out in the paddock and the ground will be our Bed.
looking from where I am writing this note one Sees nothing but long lines of transports of all Decriptions



(98)

from this position I can See 20 or 30 thousands horses and thousands of limber waggon guns motor and horse ambulance tents cookers and thousands of troops one cannot but praise the wonderful system of organization

(99)

that exists in the British army. aeroplanes are sauring overhead and observation Balloons are all over the place. the 14th and 15th Battalions go into the trenches tomorrow morning. the is some talk that the 13th will not go in again on this

(100)

front. our new MO is a fine chap and ought to go well under fire phillips has left for good and a good jobtoo

Randell went to F A this morning

(101)

time 7.30 pm

Banney and I have just had a look at Bouzincourt there is nothing to see in the village it ispractically Deserted By the civilians population. one noticeable thing is that you can not See one place that has been affected by the German Shells



(102)

it is raininglike one thing and everything pointsthat we are going to get wet before morning
We are camped in the openfields 

(103)

(105)
Entry.82:
Sausage Gulley

Back once more in Sausage Gulley after about 10 Days away things have changed in this valley since we were here last all the guns have moved up closer to the german lines there is not much traffic on this road now it all comes up the Boiselle rd. the 14th and 15th Btn went into the line last night the 13 and
Entry.83:
releive them tomorrow some time there is three Big guns on our right and every time they fire they almost makeones Stomach come up to his mouth

(106)

it is raining like one thing at present we all got Drenched this morning coming from albert who tobe our has Been given command of the 13 Battalion. he his a fine chap and one that all the boys like has gone to england to command one of the training Battalions

time 2 pm

the sun has come outand things point going to have a nice afternoon

(107)

time 6 pm

the sun is now shining Bright and the guns are going like one thing the air is infested by our aeroplanes the germanare trying to Bring them Down with Schrapnelthe germans have started to Bombard our position from where I am

(108)

standing I can See where they have just 4 Big Jack Johnsons. our guns have been giving them Hell this last 20 minutes There is nothing

(109)

But the continual of iron The German have Started to lengthen their range the cause of the fire is some aeroplanes have Discovered a Body of huns

(110)

troops coming up to reinforce those in the trench theywill have Suffered heavily in action.

(111)

god help those who are under our fire. time 7pm The fight Still goes on the artillery is more active than at 6 pm. I am writing this account in Sausage Gulley we have only returned to it this morning after 10 days absence we are getting a

(112)

Lively reception on our return to what we call our home are we Downhearted no not untill they come a Bitcloser and then I am afraid we will be. fritz is getting 3 Shells forevery one that he is putting over. they are all Jack Johnsons that are being

(113)
Entry.84:
Sausage Gulley

more Rain today and more Discomfort too there was violent artillery Duels last night the german knocked 2 of our 18 poundersout of action. The Battalion has received orders that they are going to releive the 15th at midnight and will make their stunt tomorrow night. The
Entry.85:
attacked last night and Both it and the 15 were cut up. Jack Brown paid us a visit this morning he has had 

(114)
Entry.86:
time 7 pm. Things have just begun to Brighten up There is about 15 of our aeroplanes and about 50 observation Baloons in the air the Germans had 5 of their planes over this evening But they Did not venture over our lines and to good care to keep up
Something like 1000 feet. they will not show fight with our Boys if they can possableavoid it. fritz also has 4 Baloons up. we have just received word to Dump our Blankets on account of going into the trenches at midnight

(115)
Entry.87:
this afternoon the artillery officer Sang out to his men roumania has Declared war against austraia. give them a salvo and they Did. This is good news for us now we have things in the Balkans in our own hands we can now stop Germany from Doing any Damage in that particular theatre of the front. the germans have not Shelled the gulley today. sickparade was held at 2.30 pm noone was sentaway the Doc also gave a lecture to the Stretcher Bearers on the art of Bandaging we are sure to get a warm reception going in tonight anyhow lets hope no one gets hurt

left SausageGulley last night

(116)
Entry.88:
1916

once again we are settled Down in the Dressing Station the same that we occupied when we were here a fortnight ago

time 7 pm. the Doc left here this afternoon to go to the front line trenches to have a look at a Dug out. if its is suitable we are going to make our D.S there then we will be in the front line trenches. has just received a notice from the Doc to pack up and go up to the line he has Desideredto occupy the Dug out.
time 9.30. we have at last arrived in our new DS and it is not too Bad things are quiet at present. We expect



(117)

a busy night on account of an attack that the 13 and 16th Btn are making they are attacking farm again. this will be the second time that the Btn attackedit. last time the Btn Did well But were compelled to retire through the fault of another Battalion
Entry.89:
the trenchs on the Somme

things have been very Busy During the night. the attack last night was a failure and our Boys have been cut up very Badly. in all we put through about 80 cases last night and some of the poor chaps are mauled about Something terriable I will not give any account of the attack

(118)

30th August
time 5 pm

we are being kept Busy again today getting more wounded in and others. we have about 8 stretchers cases waiting to be removed But I am afraid it is to late to get any more of them away tonight the amc bearers will take them in the morning. we are releived sometime tonight
Entry.90:
albert
once again we are Back in albert and how pleased we all are to be away from that hell up there. one cannot write what he really thinks But this time has Been hell and no Doubt









(119)

we left the Dressing Station this morning about 9 pm and as we were coming away light we Brought out a few Stretcher cases with us we did not Bring them through the Saps because they were to Sloppy and impassable to make way through them so what we Did Do was to tie a tringular bandage on to the end of a stick and Bring them over no mans land we all got across without any Damage. all the same a few Shells Droped pretty close to us of course they were not fired at us. if then the germanSnipers wished they could have Shot the lot of us But they let us come along our own way

(120)

and we allow them to go across unmolested that is if they carry a flag. we are leaveing here at 5 pm this evening for Warloy which we will Do in about 2½ hours marching and I can tell you I am none too strong for the journey my feet are aching and we have not had a change of clothes for about 5 days But we Dont cry we all grin and bear it. So are we Downhearted no I don't think So

(121)

France
Entry.91:
on the march to Rubempre from warloy

left warloy this morning at 9.15 for Rubemprewhich is about 8 miles Distance the time is now about 1 oclock and we have pulled up alongside of the road for Dinner. The Brigadier has just had us on parade and gives the Brigade great praise for their work on the western front. he said that if general Birdwood wanted a Brigade of aust to do a ticklish job he would Select the 4th Brigade. to Do it we will be in the trenches in a weeks time and where we are going is Ypres

(122)

where the Canadians have just left they are releiving the australians on the Somme. we will reach Rubemprein about another hours march. Snowy Gillman was killed in the attack on mouquet farm also Cpl Dingle Both fine Boys

gillespie and Solomon missing

the 1st Canadian Divisional HQ are in Rubempre. passed through vadencourt and contay.
three Battalions are making another attack on the farm tonight lets all hope they

(123)

Successful because there has Been a good many casualties there allready and it is still inthe germans hands the Brig says that the allies have practally Bought Bulgaria over and that they will be on our side shortly. the Kingis finished and his successor says he wontfight against the russians so things in the Balkans are particularly Bright for the allies The British are attacking all along the line from Theipval to Guillemont tonight poor old fritz he his getting a roughtime of it lately. receiveda letter from mabs last night

(124)

time 4 pm

have just arrived in Rubempre after seven hours marching from Warloy things are just the same here as when we were here last time the are plenty of canadian troops here at presentthere was a great hullaboloo in the Billet when we Brought the A M.C. cart in the yard madarm went crook because we brought the mule in and was throwing her arms about in all Directions and Shouting eventually we quietened her

pay Day tomorrow

(125)
Entry.92:
Rubempre
Somme District

received 20 francsthis morning from D Compthere is a parade this afternoon at 4 oclock when general Birdwood will present military medals won in the recent push on the Somme there will be a good many given out we remain in this Billet for a few days and then go on to Ypres Salient 33 on Sick parade this morning no one sent to 

general Birdwood presented Military Medal Ribbons this afternoon Cock Wild received his. the ceremony was a simple one there is a

(126)

Brigade concert at 7 pm. Sgt Clark and Joe Banney are Both recommendedfor a Military Medal Both belong to the 13th Btn a m c good luck to them they Both Deserve what they get may it a victoria cross. The Doc is for a D.S.O. he also Deserves what he gets also

(126)
Entry.93:
Rubempre

nothing Doing today we have received order that we resume our march tomorrow morning at 9
Entry.94:
Montrelet

after about 6 hours marching we have arrived in montrelet and things point that this is a Dead place nothing unusual occured on the march

(127)
Entry.95:
Montrelet

nothing Doing today raining a little we leave here in the morning
Entry.96:
Gezincourt 

we marched from montrelet to the above named village the Distance being 6 miles. the place is a little larger than those which we have passed through During our Sojourn on the Somme front line also entrain here on the 8th for the north

5th Sept 1916

(129)

Montrelet

raining here today this village is only a small one and you cannot buy anything in it every village that we have been Billeted in Seems to be the same we are leaveing here tomorrow morning for somewhere we may and we may not entrain here for Ypres

nothing else
Au Re Voir

(130)
Entry.97:
Gezaincourt

nothing much Doing here today we have received Definite orders that we leave here tomorrow morning we entrain at Doullens for Ypres which is almost 6 hours run from here. the 1st and the 2nd anzac Divisions are in the trenches at Ypres we are supposed to go in on the 11th of this month we will strike the gas there. the Somme Battle is going good for us

(131)
Entry.98:
Belgium

This morning at 6.15 we left Doulleens and landed at our Destination at 12.30. after having Dinner we started to march for this village the name of which I have not found out at 2 pm the Distance we had to make being about 3 miles.
the train journey was very nice after travelling about the Somme District none of us are sorry to get away from there although we all realise that the

(132)

the stouch about these parts are no joke. the gallant Canadians have withstood the German onslaught for the past 18 months and I am surewe can do the same as them. time 9 oclock nightat the present moment there is falling heavey artillery fire going on upin the line But not so bad as round pozieres we have received a gas alert and all the men are waiting with their gas helmets for the gas to come close enough to us this place certainly looks as if it has not Been affectedBy that Deadly poision

(133)

it turns anything a yellow color and perhaps will Do the same to us that isif it comes close enough and we are sure to get it hot and strong in the Ypres Salient where the australians are now fighting. General Birdwood says if we can get our helmets on in 9 or 10 seconds we are allright we not too the germans dont allow us enough time to get ready for them. I wentto the Y.M.C.A hut tonight and heard

(134)

Dr McGrath lecture on the allies east and west and the present situation the lecture was not of a very enlighting character.

a yarntold By Dr McGrath tonight.
a general was paying a vicit to the front line trenches and was very Strict about the men wearing their helmets. Coming along his AD.C said excuse me Sir you have not your helmet. the G turned in Disgust and startted Blaming

(135)

others for not Supplying him with one Before he left H.Q. Seeing a pte Standing close By the called out come here my man Show me your gas helmet Sorry Sir said the pte I have Strict orders not to give my hat to any Body. yes I know that said the G But you can get one from Q.M.S this Done the G walked round and spotted a outside his his Dug out without his helmet in great rage the G



(136)

said where is your gas helmet the being taken unawares try to say that it was inside. fancy seeing an officer without it I could expect to find the ptes without one But an officer its outragerous here take my said the general and let meSee you put it on while I count three 1 2 3 the gave one heave and pulled out 2 pair of Dirty socks this is a Dinkumtale

rather hard on the general concerned Dont you think

(137)

time 10 pm
I am soon going to Bed and or try to have a good nights rest au re voir
Entry.99:
in Belgium

on the Ypres front there is fairly heavey artillery Duels going on we are 10 miles behind the line and I canhear the big guns Bursting very plainly I am led to believe that the germans have some Big guns on this front there is one thing certain and

(137)

that is theycant be any worse here than on the Somme where there is a violent Battle now raging and going well for the allies. the Doc said that I must take some for my cold he heard me coughing last night. wouldent it be a shame if he Sent me away to hospital

There is a concert onin the Y.M.C.A. hut tonight which I am going too
have tried to Gain admittance to the concert But one cannot get within

(138)

20 yards of the Door it is packed like sardines

(139)
Entry.100:
9th 16
Reninghelst

Still resting nothing Doing here at present this place is better than those which we have just left behind us in france we are now in Belgium

(140)

and there is a lot more english Spoken here than france. We have no idea when we go into the trenches here But I Dont Suppose it will be long. received a few papers from home this morning But no letters

(141)
Entry.101: nothing Doing today we are Still in Billets
Entry.102: very cold here today nothing Doing otherwise
Entry.103:

Entry.111:
in the trenches at Ypres

as usual things have been very quiet indeed coming from the Somme one could not beleive that things could be so quiet on certain Sectors of the front Joe Banney has been in the front line since we came into the tenches. today the a.d.m.s. was round and he wanted to know where the Details were. the Doc told him that he was in the front line he has now received orders to withdraw him at once Bill Clark returned from England last night he told us that he has had a Bonny time I am now wishing for my turn to come along quicker than ever

(154)

Since coming into these trenches it makes it the seventh time that I have been into the fireing line and carry a Bullet mark for each occasion I suppose I will be in many more times before the war is finished whenever that may be I am sureI have no idea But there is one thing certain and that is I will not be Sorry when the guns fire their last Shot and we all return to those that are dear to us. I went to head quarters 3 times today with the sick reports. wrote to Essie mabs and mrs Cooper a few Days ago

Signed pteMcClintock

Entry.134:
in the trenches at Ypres

the time is now about (8 oclock night) this morning I came up with the Doctor to hold sick parade and he Desided to leave me up here to look after the men with Sores on them and there is a good many of them. I have pills of all Description with me also ointments



and to make Solution in fact I am an emergency Doctor

I am camped in the tunnells whichare about 40 feet Deep and it would take a Big Shell to make any affect on it It will Do me for the Duration of the war and I am no hero McKerlie and I went Down to HQ for my gear one thing I left behind was a Basin which was very important the Distance from here to HQ is fully three miles and takes about 75 minutes to walk this afternoon the huns threw a lot of rum jars over no Battalion men hit McCarthy returned this morning minus

his mostaucewhich makes him look a knut. received word from the Base yesterday cablegram Despatched to head on the 7th of the month money oughtto be in London By now. my leave Should come in about 3 weeks time the Sick parade this morning was fairly Big. three men Sent to ambulence which is at Bedford house.

Cane turned up this morning. he was tried and given 21 days no 2 field punishment that means forfit 21 Days pay at 6/- per 

nothing more at present

Entry.136:

our aeroplane which was well over the german lines unfortunately he fell on german ground the conduct of our airman is wonderful the come out amongst us and are Subjected to very violent fire from the german anti aircraft

guns. But they just ride through the clouds as we would on parade Every British Soldier will allways Be proud to lift his hat to men of the royal air Service

the time is now about 8 oclock and we are just going to make Some coffee before 
re

oh dont we Soldiers live high oh I am Sure we do But at our own expence I have Spent about 20 francs Since coming into the trenches

 opinion on concription

in a couple of Days time we will be called upon to vote yes on the concription Bill But will the troops vote yes. I say they will not and quite right too we ourselves are volunteers and will not help to force men against their wish. if they cannot See that it is their Duty to come let them Stop away. a very unjust thing about the voteing is all under 21 years of age are not allowed a (vote)no But they can and are allowed to come away and give their lives this is not takeing into consideration

one noticable thing about the Exemptions are that all men who are the Sole Support of their parents are Exempt But what about those who were the Sole Support of their parents and came over here and have Died for their country and those that are liveing will they be recalled to look after their aged parents oh Dear no they are now soldiers and do not count we all want the allies to win this war and we will win there is not the Slightest Doubt about that

But I think that we can do it without concription in australia Billy Hughes is going to do himself and his government a lot of harm he Seems to has caught that complaint that we do not want in aust and that is to much wait and See

things are rather tame here today I went to abbeville last night and was impressed with what I Seen there it is the best place that I Been in Since I arrived in this country Some 5 months ago. about 50 on Sick parade this morning one goes to FA

heard on Sick parade

right let them come. the words are addressed to one of the amc BoysStanding at the Door with the names of the who wish to See the Doctor. very good Sir.
in comes the first.whats your name, - patient SmithSir.
m.o. yes what are you complaining of - patient kindney troubleSir
m.o. how do you know its kidney trouble who told you you were Suffering you ought to know that you come here for me to tell whats wrong with you -patient yes Sir But - -
m.o. yes I know all about that lets have a look at



your back and See if I can find any trace of Kindney Disease -patient, will I take my coat off Sir.
mo yes thats right just hold your Shirt up there.here the mo taps the patients back Several times Does that hurt - patient no.
mo Does that, and giveing him a harder tap further up the Back - patient oh yes Sir.
mo right put your coat on. - the patient Starts to dress again.
mo how long have you noticed your kindneys were out of order

patient, about a month Sir.
mo why Dident you come to me before and have it looked at -patient, I Dident think it Serious enough Sir.
mo were you ever troubled with your kidney - Patient yes Sir I was in hospital for about a month with them Before I enlisted and when the cold weather comes the pain at times is unbearable.
mo yes But Did you not think at the time you going up you would not make a good Soldier. - patient I thought it would wear off Sir.
mo what reason did you have to think so -patient well Sir I thought the warm climate in Egypt would Do it good

mo But Surely you Did not Expect to Stop in Egypt all the time - Did you you know there is not much fighting going on there and you came away from australia with the intentions of going anywhere you were Sent. Isent that right - patient yes sir.
here the mo goes to his medical orderly and they put their heads together and Decide to give him a no 9 and Duty.
