Entry.162:
Somewhere Nearthe trenches
on the Somme

We have just arrived at this from Rehemont which is about 12 kilos away we left Rehemont at 9 this morning the time is now 4 oclock there is 2 companies out of each Battalion in the Brigade Doing fatigue Duty. we are camped just By Fricourt wood where there was Some Heavey fighting at the Beginning of the Somme offencive. looking from my tent one cannot But wonder and certainly cannot praise the wonderful organization that I am watching at the

the present moment there is a road not more than 800 yards away and there is allways 10 miles of traffic on it - motor lorries horses transport motor ambulences horseman and many other things to numerous to mention. I thought that I had Seen the wonderful way the British army work But I am now Sure that I knew nothing and Seen less Before today when I arrived in the valley. all last night our guns were pounding at the huns for all they were worth there is not the Slightest Doubt about it that the germans must be completely Demoralised By our Shell fire The Canadians advance to day and are Still holding the ground now the french Scored a Success on the right
Entry.163:
Fricourt wood

things have Been pretty Busy here today the artillery are Still pouring iron into the huns poor fritz. today has Been one of the Best that I have Seen for the past fortnight. as I Sit and write up todays Events there is one thing which appeals to me and that is the Limber waggons and horses that are passing notthat they are paintedpretty But Because the amount mudthey are carring the the wheels a chockablock the axls the same in fact the whole waggon is covered with mud and there



is the horses and the harness that they wear they are every Bit as bad as the waggons the mud is awfuland many of our Boys are suffering from trench feetwhich is not the Best of Diseases that trouble the troops. I met Beatty Moffats Brother this morning he is inthe 17th Battalion and told me that most of that battalion were Suffering from trench feet and the Doctor Declared them unfit for further active Service on this attack I met young McKer from Bathurst yesterday he was marching along the Road with his Battalion and called out hullo mac how goes it must Be 8 years ago Since I last Seen him its marvellous how he knew
Entry.164:
in Death Valleyon the Somme front

today has Been rather a Busy one for me at 10 thismorning I took Sick parade over tothe DAC Doc he Sent 2 men to FA there names were and Kebblewhite all this occupied the Best part of the morning and then I had to take them to the 5th field ambulence which is notless than miles return this afternoon I went with mr to the Doc I am glad to say that there is nothing wrong with this fine chap the Battalion passed about oclock they are gone 3 miles further into the valley

we move up to them in the morning at 8 am things have Been very active all day our guns are still Supplying the germanswith iron rations from where I am siting I can count thirty Balloons on the french and British posts and about 40 aeroplanes (ours of course) fritz only Dares to come out on a moonlight night this Battalion are going into the line on last night we were told thatthe germans carried out a zepplin raid on London with 37 zeps and caused 4000 casualties and there was 6 zeps Brought Down this will make our men more eager to get at the huns why Dont we Bombard open towns the Same as them. our mottoShould be an Eye for an Eye
Entry.165:
1916|
Death Valleyon the Somme

By jove its coldhere today one can hardly feel anything at all on account of our limbs being numbed So much about 4 this morning our artillery opened up on the germans and they have not ceased fireing the time now is 4 pm our troops captured 500 prisoners and the English 3500 last night we have Bapume cut off on Both flanks we should capture it within 3 Days from today we were Supposed to move this morning But it was cancelled and we have no idea when we will move

now.
Three men were Sent to F ambulence this morning thier Names be Hansen and who had a V.C I have Sent all the Sick reports along to old Bill by pte Fordwho goes his way tonightSometime nothing more to report all well at the Theatre. Theatre of war I mean not the one in Castlereagh St Syd
Entry.166:
on the Somme

I have now rejoined the other 2 Companies of the Battalion we left Death Valley at 9 this morning and marched about miles to wherewe are now camped I arrived at 4 pm with the water cart
Entry.167:
on the Somme

today is one of the Best that I have Seen for the past month or So the Sun came out and Bright this morning. No casualties in this valley from Shot or Shell Bill Clark was Evacuated this morning to FA and reccomended

By the Doctor for aust I hope that he has the Luck to get through Because has Done his Bit as much as the Next one has au Revoir Bill
Entry.168:
on the Somme

oh Christ its cold today when we woke up this morning the frost was on the ground 2 inches thick and our feetwere all frozen By jingo it was cold and no Doubt about it the time is now 2.30 and the frost has all melted and the ground is very muddy and sloppy

indeed how we are going to Stand a winter here I Do not know why the men will not be able to Stand the cold Just take this morning for insance it was you might say the first cold Day that we have had and the result was 45 men reported Sick out of the 45 there was 2 Evacuated to F.A During one month there was Seventeen thousandSick cases alone pass through the Canadian Stations Capt say he is going to Sleep with us tonight wont he have a good Sleep I Dont think. I willcough all night long. yesterday Clark went away and Since then I have received the Biggest Set Back that Ireceived Since joining the army over 2 years ago

a 12th reinforcement man has Been reccomend for promotion to corpral over 2 of us. why or what for I Do not know. Workman is all right I have nothing against the man But I Do Blame Capt who Does not in this case give justice to whom justice is Due. when Workman went to See him yesterday he told the Doc that there were 2 men Senior to him in the AMC But the Doc saidoh you are the Naturaly I am annoyed at this promotion and why Shouldent I be. anyhow there is one thing Sure and that is that I have allways Done my Best and if I cannot get along without crawling well I will allways remain a private with a clear mind
Entry.169:
on the Somme front

today is not a Bad one But there is Still plenty of mud on the ground we are going to remain here untill Dec 15th then we go out for a month or more a couple more men Evacuated this morning there is a great manySick men about the camp now there was 56 on parade this morning
Entry.170:
on the Somme front

there has not been much Doing today



fritz has Been putting a few more Shells on the road today But I Dont think he hurt any Body at all a couple of Days ago he Shelled the road and killed 6 horses and 2 men and wounded three men this part of the line is very quiet considering that it is a Sector of the Somme its nothing to what pozierers was one thing it could not be any worse the time is now about 9 pm and and old fritz is at the road again he only puts a few Shells across and then gives up he has not to many Shells to Spare the position that we are now in is about 4 miles from the front line

and he Does not Shell us muchthis goes to Show that he must have his guns a long way Back Because he is afraid of us making a Big advance and captureing the lot. fifteen thousand huns passed through our compounds last week as prisoners of course I am going to give up nowand Dream happy Dreams of the good times gone By.

all well on the base
Entry.171:
on the Somme front

things have not been too Busytoday fritz put a few more Shells on the road this afternoon I Do not know if he managed to catch anyone. lets hope not. I am not up to the mark to day as I have a Slight touchof indfluenza which makes things more than uncomfortable indeed no word from Bill Clark yet no Doubt he is in a cozy possie somewhere in France or Blighty nothing more
Entry.172:
Still on the Somme front

today I Seen the first aeroplane Brought Down unfortunately it was one of our own I Should Say that it was up 5000 feet when it commenced to fall to Earth and as it fell it was turning over and over and would not have given a penny for the mens lives But wonderful did Happen Sometimes and one certainly Did Happen today because neither of the 2 men were killed the observer had compound fracture of the leg while the pilot

received a Bullet in the head I Do not know wheather it was Serious or otherwise. the time is now 7.30pm and at present there is a very violent Bombardment going on By our guns By all appearence there is a Big attack about to be launched By our troops poor old Kaiser Bill Ill Bet he is Sorry that he started the war one thing his troops must get an time from our gunswho are to Be pitiedrather than Blamed

at Seven tonight we received orders to pack up

as we are leaving here tomorrow morning Between 8 and 9 oclock we are going to Carlton Camp wherever that might Be the Maltese cart is now packed and ready for the tomorrows Journey Influenza has not Improved at all
Entry.173:
on the Somme front

nothing much Doing today fritz put a few Shells over last night right in amongst the Boys tentsBut Did not hit anybody
Entry.174:
on the Somme front

today we came to Carlton Camp which is about 3 miles from the front line the Brigade go into the trenches on the 30th nothing Else Doing

25th Nov 1916
Somewhere

this morning Capt ShierlawSent me to field amb

and marked me Chronic Bronchitis I left the Battalion about 9 this morning and went to the 4th FA per ambulence car and oh what a rough ride it was too afterleaving the 4th FA we were takeing to Quarry Sideing and remained there untill 6 oclockwhen we entrained for the Clearing Stn arrived at the 5th FA about 7 oclock and from there we were put on motor lorries and Sent tothe CRS where I am at present I Do not know if I am going to remain here untill I am right or not

I am hopeing that they will Evacuate me to Hospital as I am Sure that I will not get cured at this camp I have been Suffering from this Complaint for Some months now and this is where a man is put to get right in days where months in other places have failed anyhow we will See what the future Brings forth. lets hope Dear old Blighty I think I am too unlucky to get across there This is the
Entry.175:
time that I have been a 



Since I left aust in 1914 nearly 2 years ago and I hope its the last time
Entry.176:
Corps Rest Station
on the Somme

this morning the mo came and had a look at us one man was Sent to CGS and a couple have to return to their units he ordered me three times per day and inhallation for the voice which has practally failed me During the past fortnight or so I am not feeling any Better

today the cough is Still very troublesome that I am put into hospital as that is the only place that I can possably cured at. that is I mean completely I cannot See Dear old Blighty in Sight this is not a Badcamp of its kind it is Situated near Rehemont where we were Billeted at Before we moved upto the front

all well at the Base and in Australia
Entry.177:
Corps Rest Station
on the Somme

the Doctor has just Been round the tents when he came to me he asked me how I felt and I told him not too good So he is going to keep me here untill tomorrow and if I was no Better he will Evacuate me to CCS which means that I will have to go into Hospital lets hope its Blighty I think I am too to get across there
Entry.178:
CRS on the Somme

The Doc has just been round and has Desided to give me Still another Day here and if I am no Better tomorrow he will no Doubt Send me to CCS I hope he Does as I am Sure that they cannot cure me completely at this camp I have been suffering from this complaint for some time now lets see what tomorrow Brings forth lets hope CCS and then forBlighty
